question: What is the distance between Earth and an object that is 10 light years away?

content.source_1: A light-year is a unit of length equal to the distance light travels in vacuum in one Julian year (365.25 days), about 9.4607×10^15 meters (≈9.4607×10^12 km).
content.source_2: When a distance is stated as N light-years, that denotes a spatial separation of N light-years; e.g., “10 light-years away” means a distance of 10 light-years in the stated unit.
content.source_3: In practice, published stellar distances in light-years are quoted in a standard astronomical frame tied to the solar-system barycenter (e.g., the ICRS), implicitly adopting that frame’s simultaneity convention.
content.source_4: In special relativity, “distance at the same time” between spatially separated objects is frame-dependent because simultaneity is relative; different inertial frames assign different instantaneous separations.
content.source_5: The problem statement does not specify a reference frame or simultaneity convention, so—absent an adopted convention—there is no unique value for the instantaneous Earth–object distance.
content.source_6: Earth’s orbital motion changes the instantaneous Earth–star separation by up to ~2 AU over a year; 1 AU ≈ 8.3 light-minutes ≈ 1.58×10^-5 light-years, illustrating that a quoted nominal distance can vary slightly with time and chosen frame.

answer: the distance light can travel in 10 years
